presentation.title: Carbon sequestration and storage
presentation.runninghead: The values associated with ecosystems' ability to sequester and store CO2, removing it from the atmosphere.
presentation.description: The values associated with ecosystems' ability to sequester and store CO2, removing it from the atmosphere.

page.name: CO2 sequestration and storage assessment
page.title: Introduction
page.description:
This storyline computes estimates of carbon sequestration by terrestrial ecosystems - the net removal of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere and the avoidance of CO2 emissions from terrestrial ecosystems into the atmosphere via fire or deforestation. CO2 uptake from the atmosphere largely occurs via photosynthesis. This carbon is stored as plant biomass (in the trunks, branches, leaves and roots of the plants) and organic matter in the soil. Terrestrial carbon sequestration depends on a series of factors including climatic conditions, vegetation structure and successional stage, and land use practices.

In ARIES, we distinguish between ecosystem sources where carbon sequestration occurs. We also map sinks, or areas at risk of releasing stored carbon, largely via fire or deforestation. By subtracting the amount of stored carbon release from carbon sequestration in a region of interest, we are left with the carbon remaining available to offset anthropogenic emissions. These greenhouse gas emitters are the beneficiaries of carbon sequestration and storage. Since greenhouse gas emitters benefit from the waste absorption capacity of the biosphere, carbon sequestration and storage can be divided among emitters. Existing and proposed systems to cap and assign property rights to atmospheric greenhouse gas emissions use this framework. In other words:

Carbon sequestration (source) – stored carbon release (sink) = carbon available to offset emissions (use)

By mapping levels of carbon sequestration, stored carbon release, and anthropogenic emissions in a common unit (tonnes C/ha.yr), we can fully describe regional carbon balances – the level of a region’s net release or uptake of atmospheric CO2. This will become increasingly important as local, state, and national governments continue to inventory greenhouse gas emissions and implement strategies to address climate change. Use of ecosystem carbon sequestration is rival and occurs at the global scale through atmospheric mixing.
page.see-also:
Carbon model details from the ARIES website
IPCC website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual evapotranspiration
page.title: Actual evapotranspiration
page.description:
Actual evapotranspiration has a strong relationship with primary productivity (hence carbon sequestration, and indirectly carbon storage), becoming particularly important in water-limited environments.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to the sequestration (source) and potential stored carbon release (sink) models.

Representation

Data are in physical units of mm/year.

Source

SAGE/University of Wisconsin.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: SAGE Atlas of the Biosphere.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil C:N ratio
page.title: Soil C:N ratio
page.runninghead: Ratio of carbon to nitrogen in soils
page.description:
The ratio of carbon to nitrogen in soils influences the rate of carbon sequestration. In some ecosystems, carbon sequestration and storage are predicted to be greater under higher soil C:N ratio values.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to the sequestration model.

Representation

Data are a unitless ratio of soil carbon:nitrogen content.

Source

Derived from FAO Global Soils data.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: FAO Global Soils database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Seasonal temperature range
page.title: Summer - winter temperature range
page.runninghead: Difference between mean summer high and winter low temperatures
page.description:
The difference between mean summer high and winter low temperatures can be a meaningful predictor of ecosystem net primary production.

Role in models

These data were derived from global mean temperature data and are used as an input in the ARIES carbon sequestration and storage models. Seasonality is predicted to affect carbon sequestration and storage, with greater sequestration and storage under lower seasonal temperature variability.

Representation

Data are in physical units of degrees Celsius.

Source

Derived from PRISM Climate Group, Oregon State University (U.S.); WorldClim (global).
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: WorldClim, PRISM.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Successional stage
page.title: Successional stage
page.description:
The stage of vegetation regrowth following a disturbance event. The rate of succession, type of late successional plant community, and importance of succession in predicting ecosystem carbon sequestration and storage will vary widely in different ecosystems. Generally, greater carbon storage is predicted in late-successional ecosystems, with greater sequestration predicted in early- to mid-successional ecosystems.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project for western Oregon and Washington.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:
Tree canopy cover influences both carbon sequestration and storage in most environments. We generally predict greater carbon sequestration and storage in areas with greater tree canopy cover.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage.

Representation

Data are the percentage of the ground surface covered by tree canopy.

Source

National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD, U.S.); GLCF (University of Maryland, global).
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: National Land Cover Dataset, University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hardwood:softwood
page.title: Hardwood:softwood ratio
page.runninghead: The ratio of hardwood to softwood tree species
page.description:
Softwood and hardwood tree species grow at different rates, thus sequestering and storeing atmospheric carbon differently. Generally, we assume softwoods will grow and sequester carbon at a greater rate early in their life, while hardwoods will grow more slowly (i.e., sequester less carbon annually) but will store more carbon in mature hardwood forests.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project for western Oregon and Washington or reclassification of local forest type data.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual precipitation
page.title: Mean annual precipitation
page.description:
Ecosystems in regions with greater mean annual precipitation generally have greater carbon sequestration and/or storage. Precipitation is particularly important in water-limited environments, where annual variation in precipitation strongly influences annual carbon sequestration.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage, particularly in arid environments.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation.

Source

PRISM Climate Group, Oregon State University (U.S.); WorldClim (global).
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: WorldClim, PRISM.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Land cover
page.title: Land cover
page.description:
Different land cover types have different carbon sequestration rates and different capacity to store carbon.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage across ecosystems such as forests, grasslands, and urban areas.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD).
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different plant communities have different carbon sequestration rates and different capacity to store carbon.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage across ecosystems such as forests, grasslands, and urban areas.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Southwest Regional GAP Analysis (SWReGAP) land cover data.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analayis land cover data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different plant communities have different carbon sequestration rates and different capacity to store carbon.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage across ecosystems such as forests, grasslands, and urban areas.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Southwest Regional GAP Analysis (SWReGAP) land cover data.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analayis land cover data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different plant communities have different carbon sequestration rates and different capacity to store carbon.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage across ecosystems such as forests, grasslands, and urban areas.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

USDA Forest Service/CALVEG vegetation type data.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: CALVEG vegetation data, distributed by USDA Forest Service.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different plant communities have different carbon sequestration rates and different capacity to store carbon.

Role in models

Data are used as an input to compute carbon sequestration and storage across ecosystems such as forests, grasslands, and urban areas.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service Cropland Data Layer.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Forest degradation
page.title: Level of forest degradation
page.description:
Degraded forests are expected to sequester and store less carbon than healthier forests.

Role in models

Forest degradation data are available for Madagascar, a nation with high deforestation rates and levels of forest degradation. In degraded forests, we expect lower levels of carbon sequestration and storage.

Representation

Data are categorical, and identify degraded forest and savanna ecosystems.

Source

Foiben-Taosarintanin'i Madagasikara (FTM), Madagsacar national land cover.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Foiben-Taosarintanin'i Madagasikara.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Atmospheric CO2 removed
page.title: Carbon sequestration
page.description:
CO2 sequestered. The amount of carbon taken up by vegetation and soils and added to biotic and soil carbon stocks. This is the quantity available for mitigating anthropogenic carbon emissions.

Role in models

The value of the area in mitigating the adverse effects of rising atmospheric CO2 is indicated by the amount of carbon sequestered by vegetation and soil.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon sequestered per hectare per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of carbon. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area. MODIS net primary productivity data are used for Bayesian network training.
page.see-also:
Carbon model details from the ARIES website
IPCC website
page.credits:
Data source: MODIS net primary productivity data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil pH
page.title: Soil pH
page.description:
Role in models

Soil pH influences soil carbon storage. At low pH, fungi and microbes responsible for soil respiration are less common and active, resulting in greater buildup of soil organic matter. At high pH, soils more commonly contain carbonate rocks that store carbon. Many high-pH soils also contain clays that can strongly adhere to carbon-containing organic matter.

Representation

Data are in physical units on the pH scale.

Source

SSURGO soils data (U.S.); FAO data (global).
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: USDA-NRCS SSURGO soils database, FAO Soils Database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Population
page.title: Population density
page.description:
In tropical nations with high direct dependence on forests for firewood and other ecosystem goods, higher population density can lead to lower levels of forest carbon storage as woody debris and biomass are removed for direct human use.

Role in models

These data are used to estimate the quantity of carbon stored in vegetation, with less carbon storage assumed at greater population density in rural subsistence economies.

Representation

Data are in physical units of persons per square kilometer. Gaston et al. (1998) define our discretization in modeling population density effects on carbon storage.

Source

LANDSCAN global population density (Oak Ridge National Laboratory).
page.see-also:
Gaston, G., et al. 1998. State and change in carbon pools in the forests of tropical Africa. Global Change Biology 4: 97-114.
Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Oak Ridge National Laboratory.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope
page.title: Slope
page.description:
Soil on steep slopes can be more easily washed away, particularly in the absence of protective vegetation.

Role in models

Areas on steep slopes are predicted to have lower levels of soil carbon storage, all else being equal.

Representation

Data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Derived from a global 90 m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Derived from Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil oxygen
page.title: Soil oxygen conditions
page.runninghead: The presence of wetlands with anoxic soils
page.description:
The presence of oxygen (aerobic environments) in soils allows respiration to take place, with CO2 being released. In anaerobic environments such as wetlands, minimal soil respiration occurs, and greater buildup of soil carbon can occur (though generation of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas often also occurs). Declining water tables that cause wetland degradation can also allow oxidation of soil carbon, reducing their carbon storage.

Role in models

Greater soil carbon storage is expected in wetland than upland environments, all else being equal. We currently do not consider the role of methane production by wetlands in the ARIES carbon models.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of wetlands.

Source

Land cover data, such as the National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD, U.S.), GLC2000 (global), or CORINE (Europe) datasets are used to identify the presence of wetlands.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: National Land Cover Dataset, Global Land Cover 2000 Dataset,CORINE European Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation carbon storage
page.title: Carbon storage in vegetation
page.description:
CO2 stored in vegetation.

Role in models

Vegetation carbon storage is calculated using a Bayesian model, then is summed with soil carbon storage to estimate total carbon storage in terrestrial ecosystems. Estimates of the risk of fire, deforestation, or land use change can then be used to estimate potential stored carbon release.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon stored in vegetation per hectare. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of carbon. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area. National Biomass and Carbon Dataset (NBCD, U.S.) and ORNL-CDIAC biomass data (global) are used for Bayesian network training.
page.see-also:
Carbon model details from the ARIES website
IPCC website
page.credits:
Data sources: National Biomass and Carbon Dataset, CDIAC-ORNL global biomass carbon map.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil type
page.title: Soil type
page.description:
Different soil orders support different levels of soil carbon storage.

Role in models

Soil type and mean annual precipitation are used as influnces on soil carbon storage.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Digitized from USDA-NRCS data.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil carbon storage
page.title: Carbon storage in soils
page.description:
CO2 stored in soils.

Role in models

Soil carbon storage is calculated using a Bayesian model, then is summed with vegetation carbon storage to estimate total carbon storage in terrestrial ecosystems. Estimates of the risk of fire, deforestation, or land use change can then be used to estimate potential stored carbon release.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon stored in soils per hectare. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of carbon. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area. The FAO Global Soils Database was used for Bayesian network training.
page.see-also:
Carbon model details from the ARIES website
IPCC website
page.credits:
Data source: FAO Global Soils database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation and soil carbon storage
page.title: Carbon storage in vegetation and soils
page.runninghead: Carbon storage in vegetation and soils
page.description:
CO2 stored in vegetation and soils.

Role in models

This map shows the sum of vegetation and soil carbon storage, each of which were calculated using a Bayesian model. Estimates of the risk of fire, deforestation, or land use change can then be used to estimate potential stored carbon release.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon per hectare stored in vegetation and soils.

Source

This map has been generated by summing vegetation and soil carbon storage results.
page.see-also:
Carbon model details from the ARIES website
IPCC website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Mountain pine beetle damage class
page.title: Mountain pine beetle damage class
page.description:
Mountain pine beetle _(Dendroctonus ponderosae)_ is native to western North American forests. Periodic mountain pine beetle outbreaks impact multiple ecosystem services in these regions by killing large numbers of native pines.

Role in models

Mountain pine beetle mortality affects forest flamability, as well as the quantity of live versus standing dead or downed wood as forest biomass in lodgepole and ponderosa pine forests.

Representation

Data show the number of pine beetle-killed trees killed per acre.

Source

USDA Forest Service aerial surveys.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: USDA Forest Service, Forest Health Protection and its partners.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Fire risk
page.title: Fire threat class
page.description:
Fires are a major landscape process that release carbon stored in biomass and soils.

Role in models

The likelihood of deforestation and fire, combined with the quantity of stored carbon in an ecosystem influence the amount of stored carbon that can be released by deforestation or fire. Fire is a strong influence on carbon dynamics in fire-adapted systems or those that have been altered by fire supression or invasive species, and is a weaker influence in colder and wetter climates.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

State or national-level data on fire frequency and/or fire prone vegetation types: The Nature Conservancy and SWReGAP fire return interval data (Arizona data), California Fire and Resource Assessment Program (California data), Oregon Department of Forestry (Oregon data), Washington Department of Natural Resources (Washington data), LANDFIRE (U.S. data).
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Data sources: TNC historical fire return intervals for Arizona and New Mexico, California Fire and Resource Assessment Program, Washington DNR fire data, Oregon Department of Forestry fire data., LANDFIRE. Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Deforestation risk
page.title: Risk of deforestation
page.description:
Areas at greater risk of deforestation are likely to lead to greater stored carbon release.

Role in models

The likelihood of deforestation and fire, combined with the quantity of stored carbon in an ecosystem, can predict the amount of stored carbon that is released during deforestation or fire. Deforestation is a particularly strong influence in the model in tropical nations with higher deforestation rates and weaker land tenure and enforcement of forest clearing laws.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

GLCF (University of Maryland) MODIS Vegetative Cover Conversion.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Potential stored carbon release
page.title: Potential release of stored carbon
page.runninghead: Potential carbon emissions from the landscape
page.description:
Potential emissions of carbon from the landscape, i.e., due to fire, deforestation, or other land use-land cover change, excluding emissions from fossil fuel combustion. To estimate actual emissions from stored carbon release rather than potential emissions, actual areas of fire, deforestation, or land use change should be overlaid by the user on the map of potential stored carbon release.

Role in models

This map is an output of the ARIES carbon model. The value of the area in mitigating the adverse effects of climate change is reduced when stored carbon in vegetation or soils is released.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon released per hectare per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the distribution probability of the amount of carbon released, based on the amount of stored carbon and the probability of fire and/or deforestation. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Carbon emissions
page.title: CO2 emission from human activity
page.description:
The beneficiaries of carbon sequestration and storage are greenhouse gas emitters who release CO2 into the atmosphere, relying on ecosystems to absorb and store carbon in order to avoid even larger rises in atmospheric CO2 than are currently seen. Our carbon use models thus display greenhouse gas emissions.

Role in models

This map is used to identify the beneficiaries of CO2 sequestration in this storyline.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon released each year due to fossil fuel combustion.

Source

Vulcan Project (U.S.); LANDSCAN population density data multiplied by EIA per capita emissions for the country or sub-national region of interest (global).
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: Vulcan Project, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Energy Information Administration.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Regional carbon mitigation surplus
page.title: Regional carbon mitigation surplus
page.description:
Flow model results estimating the amount of carbon left over for emissions offsets once local emissions and fire or deforestation effects have been taken into account.

Role in models

Calculated by subtracting annual greenhouse gas emissions and stored carbon release from carbon sequestration in order to estimate the carbon balance for the region of interest. If the value is positive, there is a surplus, and the area is capable of providing emissions offsets to users elsewhere in the world. If the value is negative, there is a deficit, and that region must rely on emissions offsets elsewhere to have a neutral regional carbon balance.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon per year.

Source

Calculated by subtracting annual greenhouse gas emissions and stored carbon release from carbon sequestration in order to estimate the carbon balance for the region of interest.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Regional carbon mitigation deficit
page.title: Regional carbon mitigation deficit
page.description:
Flow model results estimating the amount of carbon left over for emissions offsets once local emissions and fire or deforestation effects have been taken into account.

Role in models

Calculated by subtracting annual greenhouse gas emissions and stored carbon release from carbon sequestration in order to estimate the carbon balance for the region of interest. If the value is positive, there is a surplus, and the area is capable of providing emissions offsets to users elsewhere in the world. If the value is negative, there is a deficit, and that region must rely on emissions offsets elsewhere to have a neutral regional carbon balance.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tonnes of carbon per year.

Source

Calculated by subtracting annual greenhouse gas emissions and stored carbon release from carbon sequestration in order to estimate the carbon balance for the region of interest.
page.see-also: Carbon model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.
